title: What is a 1965 quarter worth? - Quora

response.answer_text: In 1965, I could take that newly-minted quarter into the Rexall drugstore where I bought my candy, and I could buy FIVE Milky Way bars that were about half the size of the bars that sell for more than a Ickes now. (If I had an extra penny, I could get a "6 for 26 cents" deal on the candy bars at Rexall on Fridays.) My mom could get a gallon of gas for her car for that shiny 1965 quarter. She might even get a nickel of change back, I can remember "gas war" gas prices going as low as 19 cents a gallon. I filled my car up a couple days ago, and gas was $3.40/gallon (premium gas in Southern California.) At Woolworth's, in 1965, I could go to the toy department and get a bag of marbles and 15 cents change with my quarter. Last time I saw marbles at Toys 'R' Us, they were about $2.50 a bag. (I can't go to Woolworth's any more, they're long gone; looks like Toys 'R' Us is going away, too.) My 1965 quarter could buy me 5 Rainbow Sherbet ice cream cones at Thrifty Drugs, or two vanilla cones and a nickel change; or a Foster Freeze Chocolate-Dip Vanilla Soft Serve. A single scoop of vanilla in a cone anywhere is a couple dollars now. A chocolate dip Foster Freeze cone is about $2.50 now. I could go on, but it depresses me. What is a 1965 quarter worth today? A lot less than it was worth in 1965! (When they came out with the new, non-silver coinage in 1965 [1964 and earlier quarters were real silver], a lot of us kids were really excited about them, and if a cashier had the new quarters, we'd swap older silver quarters to get the new coins. Boy oh boy were we dumb. Wish I could go back to 1965 and save every silver quarter, dime and half-dollar I could get my hands on!)

1965 quarters almost always go for face value.  But there is an interesting quirk of history. 1965 was a busy year for the mint, since they largely stopped coining in silver. However, there were still some silver blanks from pre-1965 accidentally mixed into the new non-silver blanks. So there were probably a few dozen 1965 quarters minted in silver. Due to their rarity, they usually go for auction in the high 4 to low 5 digit range. However, it would be a waste of time to look for such coins in change. The mintage of Washington quarters was 1.8 billion in 1965 and there are probably no more than a few dozen silver 1965 quarters. You've be just as likely to win the lotto as find such a coin in change.

Actually, there was a lot going on at the Mints during 1965 - 1967. It is true that about 1.8 billion 1965 quarters were minted for circulation. The little known fact is that the San Fran Mint did make some “Special Mint Sets” in 1966 but with a 1965 date on them. There were even some with the year 1964 on them. If you have one of these (65–67) still in the package they are worth about $13 for the set. The 64 set is not priced because none have been auctioned to the public and they are very rare (they were not supposed to be made). An MS-65 (totally uncirculated) 1965 quarter is worth $9 as per “The Red Book 2017”. Hope this helps.

Your quarter is exactly one year too new. Were it a 1964 it would have intrinsic value due to being made of silver. Since the US mint had to replace ALL the silver coins that were removed from circulation in 1965, a massive number of halves, quarters, and dimes were minted. It isn't uncommon to still find coins from that year in pocket change. Since even then dollar coins had fallen out of everyday use outside of casinos, those weren't a factor. Also, in an effort not to devalue the newly created Kennedy half dollar, a clad silver version was produced through 1969. Your 1965 is a nickel/copper clad (just as quarters are today) and worth exactly 25 cents.

Twenty-five cents as due to the change over from silver to copper-nickel coins, there were huge numbers of coins of that date minted to make up for all the silver coins being withdrawn from circulation by the government and citizens. There were also no "D" mintmarked coins produced during 1965. There were over 1 billion quarters minted with the 1965 date on them. A quarter of that date that that is in choice uncirculated condition is worth $1.00 but generally will fetch less from a dealer, if he even has a need for a copy. Good luck.

1965 quarters are not now, and never will be, rare or valuable. Over 1.8 billion were struck, by far the highest mintage of any year in the Washington quarter series. That was the first year of base metal quarters, and they needed to produce a massive number of them to offset the inevitable hoarding of the old 90% silver quarters.

Hello, To start. worth can be defined as "what someone is willing to pay for  a good or service" so, there are two reasons someone would be willing to pay more than the face value for a coin: The coin can be melted down for the base metals, and in circulation coins that would be any coin containing silver.Collectors need specific coins for a collections (year, denomination, rare error coins, etc.)So do your research on a coin if you think it could be worth more than it's face value and you will get to the point where you can spot a valuable coin quickly.  United States coins: American Coin Collection  Canadian coins: Canadian Coin Collection

A quarter is 25 cents. So 1965 of them would be $491.25. Maybe that’s not quite what you had in mind? If you meant quarters produced in the year 1965 then their value is likely to depend on many things that you didn’t mention. Their condition, what country they are from (Canada and the USA, possibly others too, have ‘quarters’ in their currency) and probably many other factors too.

If it’s dated 1965 the chances are it’s worth…. wait for it….. 25 cents. If it was dated 1964 it would be 90% silver so at current prices would be worth very roughly $3. But it’s the year after the silver was taken out of the quarters (I’m assuming it’s a US quarter here), so the chances are it’s not worth anything over its face value. If you have a proof quarter that’s part of a set it may have a modest collector’s value but in all likelihood what you’ve got is worth 25 cents.

Sorry, it's not silver. 1965 is the first year the US produced copper-nickel coins. If you want to check for silver quarters or dimes quickly, check the edge.  Left (copper) - copper-nickel Right (silver) - silver

Here’s one way to tell if it’s valuable — Has it been circulated? (From the picture, the answer is “Oh, yeah!” It looks pretty worn.) That means it’s worth 25 cents. Period. If it were in bright, uncirculated, proof, MS-65 condition (i.e.., very rare)… then it would be worth a bit more.

25¢. Stated differently - twenty-five cents. The U.S. Mint stopped making quarters with 90% silver in 1964. If you had a quarter that was one year earlier, it would be worth $2.25 based on spot as of the writing of this answer. You can see this for yourself on Current Melt Value Of Coins.

Not much, about 25 cents. There were 1,819,717,540 quarters minted that year, so you really can’t expect a profit unless it is proof, or it is in phenomenal condition (even then, it wouldn’t be worth that much.
divide by four… Four quarters are worth one dollar. Unless you mean the year 1965, then they are most likely worth 25 cents each…unless they are uncirculated.

It’s highly unlikely. 1965 was the first year after the US stopped using 90% silver in our dimes, quarters, and half dollars. It is base metal worth about .04 for its metal content. If it had been from the previous year it would be worth about $2.85 at today’s silver prices.
It isn’t silver, and there were close to 2 billion of them minted. It’s worth 25 cents.
They are worth more than face value if in MS-63 condition or better, $9 in MS-65.  They are made of cupro-nickel clad copper and contain no silver.
Even a very nice circulated one would only be worth face value, 25 cents. Uncirculated might sell for a couple of dollars.
That's the last year that quarters were made with 88% silver, and it's worth much more than a quarter….
$1.91.  http://m.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=.25+dollars+1965+today&x=0&y=0
